children.name: to be the reason why sth happened or why sb does sth
be the reason
children.definition: to be the reason why sth happened or why sb did sth:là lý do

children.name: be the reason for/behind
examples: Nick’s teachers think that problems at home are the reason for his poor schoolwork.

children.name: be the reason why
examples: He borrowed too much money, and that’s the reason why his business failed.

children.name: be the reason (that)
examples: I knew that I had my weaknesses. Perhaps that is the reason that I was not more successful.

children.name: explain
children.definition: if a fact or situation explains sth, it helps you to understand why it happened:giải thích
examples: We were all puzzled: what could explain his sudden change of mind?

children.name: explain why/what/how
examples: She couldn’t sleep last night, which explains why she was in such a bad mood this morning.

children.name: account for
children.definition: formal to be the reason that explains why something strange or surprising happened:giải thích cho
examples: If it’s true that he was taking drugs, that would account for his strange behaviour.

children.name: motivate
children.definition: to be sb’s personal reason for doing sth:thúc đẩy
examples: Not all people are motivated by self-interest.

children.name: motivate sb to do sth
examples: It’s frustration that motivates babies to learn to walk.

children.name: lie behind
children.definition: to be the secret or hidden reason for someone’s action or behaviour:nằm đằng sau
examples: I wonder what lies behind Arthur’s sudden interest in golf?
I think that behind Tania’s aggression lay a deep insecurity about herself.

children.name: why sth happens or why sb does sth
reason
children.definition: why sth happens, or why sb does sth: lý do, nguyên do
examples: reason to do sth
This work gives me a reason to live.
reason for
People give different reasons for wanting to change jobs.
reason why
We’d like to know the reason why she didn’t accept the job.
reason (that)
The reason I called was to ask about the plans for Saturday.
One of the main reasons that she looks so good is that she has her own personal stylist.
reason behind
He explained the reasons behind the decision.
for reasons of sth
The bridge is closed for reasons of safety.
for some reasonespecially spoken for a reason that you do not know or understand:vì vài lí do
No, he isn’t here - he had to go back to Poland for some reason.
for personal/health/business etc reasons
For security reasons, there were video cameras at the school entrance.
for reasons best known to himself/herself etcfor secret reasons that other people do not know or understand:
For reasons best known to themselves, my parents were vehemently opposed to the idea.
there is no reason to do sth
There is no reason whatsoever to doubt her story.
by reason of sthformal(= because of something )
a person disqualified by reason of age
►Do not say ‘the reason of’ something. Saythe reason forsomething. Do not say ‘the reason because’ something happens. Saythe reason why/thatsomething happens.

children.name: have a reason
examples: We had many reasons to celebrate.

children.name: give a reason
examples: No reason was given for the change.

children.name: think of a reason/see a reason
examples: I see no reason why it shouldn’t work.|I can’t think of any reason why she would want to leave.

children.name: explain the reasons for something
examples: Explain the reasons for your choice.

children.name: a good reason
examples: There is usually a good reason why the price is so cheap.

children.name: the main reason
examples: The main reason for the decline in the railways is lack of investment.

children.name: a major reason
children.definition: alsoa big reasoninformal
examples: His personality was a major reason for his success.|A big reason for the decrease in smoking is the ban on cigarette advertising.

children.name: the real reason
examples: What do you think was the real reason for their decision?

children.name: a valid/legitimate reason
children.definition: a good and acceptable reason
examples: An employer can’t fire someone without a valid reason.

children.name: a compelling reason
children.definition: a very good reason for doing something
examples: There are compelling reasons to believe that this is true.

children.name: a simple reason
children.definition: one that is easy to understand
examples: I hate mobile phones, for the simple reason that it is now impossible to get away from them.

children.name: a logical reason
examples: People don’t always have logical reasons for the things they do.

children.name: the only reason
examples: The only reason he’s coming tonight is that I said you’d be here.

children.name: for legal/political/medical etc reasons
examples: The boy cannot be named for legal reasons.

children.name: for security reasons
examples: The road will be closed for security reasons.

children.name: for personal reasons
examples: He resigned for personal reasons.

children.name: for sentimental reasons
children.definition: because you like someone or something very much
examples: I wanted to keep the picture for sentimental reasons.

children.name: for obvious reasons
examples: This arrangement must be kept secret, for obvious reasons.

children.name: for no apparent reason
children.definition: for no obvious reason
examples: He tried to kill me for no apparent reason.

children.name: for some reason
children.definition: or other
examples: (alsofor some unknown reason) (= for a reason that you do not know )For some reason she felt like crying.|For some unknown reason, the curtains were always drawn.

children.name: for reasons best known to somebody
children.definition: used when you do not understand someone’s behaviour
examples: For reasons best known to herself, she decided to sell the house.

children.name: have your reasons
children.definition: have a secret reason for doing something
examples: ‘Why did he marry her?’ ‘He must have had his reasons.’

children.name: explanation
children.definition: a fact, statement, or idea that helps you to understand why sth has happened, especially when it seems difficult to understand : giải thích
examples: I don’t know why he tested positive for drugs. The only explanation I can think of is that the samples got mixed up.

children.name: find/think of/come up with an explanation
examples: Scientists have been unable to find an explanation for this phenomenon.

children.name: provide/offer an explanation
examples: This theory may provide an explanation for the origins of the universe.

children.name: a possible explanation
examples: Can anyone think of a possible explanation for why this is happening?

children.name: the most likely/probable explanation
children.definition: one that is probably true
examples: The most likely explanation is that John missed the bus.|The most probable explanation is that the water was contaminated.

children.name: a reasonable/plausible explanation
children.definition: one that is easy to believe
examples: Pilot error is the most plausible explanation for the crash.

children.name: a logical/rational explanation
children.definition: one that is based on facts
examples: Physics finally gave us a rational explanation for the atom’s strange behaviour.

children.name: there is no apparent explanation
children.definition: used when there is no explanation that you can think of
examples: There was no apparent explanation for the attack.

children.name: explanation for
examples: Scientists have offered various explanations for these changes in climate.
Can you think of any explanation for this failure?

children.name: motive
children.definition: the reason that makes sb decide to do something, especially something bad or dishonest – often used about crimes : động cơ
examples: Why would she have killed him? She has no motive.

children.name: a strong motive
examples: Barbara had a strong motive for disliking Ben.

children.name: the main motive
examples: The main motive for the killings seemed to be revenge.

children.name: the prime/primary motive
children.definition: the main motive
examples: Concern was her prime motive in visiting Mrs Green.

children.name: a possible motive
examples: The police are still thinking about possible motives for the murders.

children.name: a clear motive
examples: She had no clear motive to lie.

children.name: a hidden motive
examples: She wondered if there was a hidden motive for his departure.

children.name: an ulterior motive
children.definition: a hidden motive
examples: Did you think I had an ulterior motive for coming here?

children.name: sb’s real/true motive
examples: What were his true motives for offering her the job?

children.name: an underlying motive
children.definition: a motive that is not directly stated
examples: The treaty’s underlying motive was to make Japan a strong ally of the US.

children.name: a political motive
examples: The murders might have a political motive.

children.name: an economic motive
examples: Many people believed that there were economic motives to the decision to go to war.

children.name: mixed motives
examples: He had mixed motives for joining the army: a desire to prove himself, but also the desire to get away from his family.

children.name: have a motive
examples: Who might have had a motive for killing him?

children.name: question/suspect sb’s motive
children.definition: think that someone might have selfish or dishonest reasons for doing something
examples: They began to question the motives of the people who held positions of power.

children.name: find/establish a motive
examples: So far the police have been unable to establish a motive for the murder.

children.name: motive for/behind
examples: Police say that there is no obvious motive for the attack.
Whatever your motives for coming over, I’m glad you did.
The motives behind the decision remain obscure.

children.name: motivation
children.definition: the reason why you want to do sth : động lực, động cơ

children.name: motivation for
examples: What was your motivation for becoming a teacher?
Escape can be a strong motivation for travel.
What was the motivation for the attack?

children.name: motivation behind
examples: There is suspicion about the motivation behind the changes we are debating.
The motivation behind the decision is the desire to improve our service to our customers.

children.name: to be a good reason why sth should be done
justify
children.definition: to be the fact or situation that makes it seem right or suitable to do something that would usually be wrong or unfair:bào chữa, biện hộ
examples: There is not enough evidence to justify such accusations.
No matter what the circumstances, street violence cannot be justified.

children.name: make it right
children.definition: if you say that sth that is wrong or badmakes it rightfor you to do sth wrong or bad, you mean that it makes your action acceptable:
examples: It’s wrong to steal and nothing you can say will make it right.

children.name: make it right (for sb) to do sth
examples: Just because you know she cheats, that doesn’t make it right for you to do the same.

children.name: call for
children.definition: sth if a situationcalls fora particular behaviour or action, it is a good reason to behave or act in that way:
examples: I hear that you two are getting married. This calls for a celebration.
It was a tricky situation that called for a lot of diplomacy.

children.name: warrant
children.definition: formal if a situationwarrantsa particular behaviour or action, the situation is so bad that there is a good reason to behave or act in that way:biện hộ cho
examples: Patients will only be given morphine if their medical condition warrants it.
The offences he has committed are not serious enough to warrant a full investigation.

children.name: why sth is right or should be done
argument
children.definition: a set of reasons that show that sth is true or untrue, right or wrong etc : lý lẽ
examples: a strong/ convincing/ powerful argument
We need to provide a convincing argument as to why the system should be changed.
I don't think that's a very strong argument.
argument for/againsta reason why something should or should not be done
What are the arguments for the legalization of cannabis?
The main argument against smoking is that it’s bad for your health.
A good argument can be made for comparing the IT revolution with the invention of writing itself.
argument in favour of
the arguments in favour of banning tobacco advertising
argument that
the familiar argument that the costs outweigh the benefits

children.name: reason
children.definition: a fact that makes it right or fair for sb to do sth : lý do
examples: The reason why we need these laws is to protect children from violent adults.

children.name: reason to do sth
examples: I can think of lots of reasons to get married.
You may be dissatisfied, but is that sufficient reason to resign?

children.name: have reason to do sth
examples: She has reason to feel guilty.
We have reason to believe that the goods were stolen.

children.name: have every reason to do sthto have very good reasons for doing sth
examples: We have every reason to believe he is guilty.
Under the circumstances, we had every reason to be suspicious.

children.name: no reason to do sth
examples: There is no reason to panic.
I know I’m late, but that’s no reason to shout at me.

children.name: with (good) reason(= based on sth sensible )
examples: Natalie was alarmed by the news, and with reason.
The school is proud of its record, and with good reason.

children.name: justification
children.definition: a good reason for doing sth that seems wrong: biện hộ, lý lẽ bào chữa
examples: She had her residence permit taken away, without any justification
justification for
There’s no justification for cruelty.
There is no justification for treating people so badly.
What justification can there be for paying women lower wages?
with some justification
It can be said, with some justification,that she is one of the greatest actresses on the English stage today.
Hoggart felt, with some justification , that his colleagues had let him down.

children.name: grounds
children.definition: the reason that makes it right or fair for sb to do sth - use this especially in legal or official contexts: lí do, căn cứ
examples: grounds for
Mental cruelty can be grounds for divorce .
There arestrong groundsfor believing his statement.
have grounds to do sth
Did the police havereasonable groundsto arrest him?
on (the) grounds of sth
Flying was ruled out on grounds of cost.
He had been fired from his job on the grounds of incompetence.
On what grounds are you claiming compensation?
‘You’re under arrest.’ ‘On what grounds?’
on moral/legal/medical etc grounds
The proposal was rejected on environmental grounds.
on the grounds that
We oppose the bill, on the grounds that it discriminates against women.

children.name: cause
children.definition: a fact that makes it right or reasonable for you to feel or behave in a particular way

children.name: a good cause
children.definition: one that is worth supporting, for example a charity
examples: The money we are raising is for a good cause.

children.name: a worthy/deserving cause
children.definition: a good cause
examples: The Red Cross is a very worthy cause.

children.name: a just cause
children.definition: an aim that is fair and right
examples: The rebels believed that they were fighting for a just cause.

children.name: a noble cause
children.definition: an aim that is morally good
examples: He died for a noble cause.

children.name: the Nationalist/Republican etc cause
children.definition: their aims and organization
examples: The election results were a serious blow to the Nationalist cause.

children.name: support a cause
examples: Giving money is only one way of supporting a good cause.

children.name: fight for a cause
children.definition: take action to achieve an aim
examples: Young people often want to fight for a cause.

children.name: champion a cause
children.definition: publicly support an aim
examples: He has championed the cause of renewable energy since the 1980s.

children.name: advance/further/promote a cause
children.definition: help to achieve an aim
examples: He did much to advance the cause of freedom.

children.name: be committed to a cause
children.definition: believe in an aim very strongly
examples: We are committed to the cause of racial justice.

children.name: be sympathetic to a cause
children.definition: understand an aim, and possibly support it
examples: They hope the new President will be sympathetic to their cause.

children.name: cause for complaint/alarm/concern etc
examples: There isno cause for alarm.
The patient’s condition isgiving cause for concern.
The present political climategiveslittlecause for optimism.

children.name: have (good) cause to do sth
examples: His father has good cause to be proud of him.
I’ve never had any cause to complain about my doctor.

children.name: with good/just causeformal chính đáng
examples: He no longer loved her, and with just cause, because she had betrayed him.

children.name: without good/just causeformal vô cớ
examples: We have little sympathy for people who leave their jobs without just cause.

children.name: rationale
children.definition: formal the reason or series of reasons that sb has used to support a plan, suggestion, change etc: cơ sở hợp lý

children.name: rationale for/behind
examples: In the document he explains the rationale for his plan to build a car for the African market.
If you do not understand the rationale behind any action you are asked to take, be sure to find out.
The rationale behind the changes is not at all evident.
The rationale for using this teaching method is to encourage student confidence.

children.name: when you have a particular reason for doing sth
have reasons
children.definition: to have a reason for doing sth - used especially when you do not want to say what that reason is:có lí do
examples: I know I don’t always explain myself, but you must always do what I say. I have reasons.
have reasons for
Each of us had reasons for wanting to leave
have reasons to do sth
I have reasons not to confide in you or anyone else.
have your reasons
I know it sounds silly but I have my reasons, believe me.

children.name: be sb’s reasons
children.definition: to be the reasons why sb does sth, especially when you know they have a reason but do not know what it is:lý do của ai đó
examples: Do you think that your decision is fair? What are your reasons?

children.name: be sb’s reasons for doing sth
examples: What were his reasons for leaving the country so quickly?

children.name: have ulterior motives
children.definition: to do sth for a secret reason when everyone thinks you are doing it for a different reason:lý do không nói ra
examples: You’re so suspicious. Whenever I buy you a present, you think I have ulterior motives.
It was difficult to accept that she had no ulterior motives. Why would she want to see the office records?

children.name: vested interest
children.definition: if you have avested interestin sth happening, you have a strong reason for wanting it to happen because you will get an advantage from it:đặc biệt quan tâm
examples: The committee should be independent of all vested interest.

children.name: have a vested interest in sth
examples: Both the newspaper and the advertising agency have a vested interest in encouraging advertising.

children.name: a reason explaining why you did sth wrong
excuse
children.definition: a reason that you give to explain why you have done something bad, or not done something that you should have done – especially one that is not completely true : lý do, lời bào chữa

children.name: make up/think up/invent an excuse
examples: I made up some excuse about my car breaking down.|We’d better think up an excuse, fast.

children.name: make excuses for somebody/something
children.definition: give reasons which try to explain why someone has made a mistake or behaved badly
examples: His mother was always making excuses for her son's behaviour.

children.name: use something as an excuse
examples: She never complained or used her illness as an excuse.

children.name: look for an excuse
examples: I began to look for excuses to avoid seeing him.

children.name: give an excuse
examples: I'll have to give my boss some kind of excuse.

children.name: believe/accept an excuse
examples: She didn’t believe his excuse for one minute.

children.name: have an excuse
examples: Companies have no excuse for breaking the law.

children.name: a good excuse
examples: A sunny day is a good excuse to go to the beach.

children.name: a wonderful excuse
children.definition: a very good excuse
examples: A wedding is a wonderful excuse to buy a new outfit.

children.name: a reasonable/plausible excuse
children.definition: one that other people will believe
examples: If your train was cancelled, that is a perfectly reasonable excuse.

children.name: a legitimate/valid excuse
children.definition: one that is true and that other people cannot criticize
examples: He didn’t have a legitimate excuse for being late.

children.name: the perfect excuse
examples: The phone call gave me the perfect excuse to leave.

children.name: a feeble/flimsy/weak excuse
children.definition: one that is difficult to believe
examples: Joe muttered some feeble excuse about having a headache.

children.name: a pathetic/lame excuse
children.definition: very weak
examples: That’s the most pathetic excuse I’ve ever heard.

children.name: the usual excuse/the same old excuse
examples: He made the usual excuses for not coming.|Whenever the trains are late, it's always the same old excuse.

children.name: a convenient excuse
examples: The rioting provided the government with a convenient excuse not to hold an election.

children.name: use every excuse in the book
children.definition: use every possible excuse
examples: He used every excuse in the book to avoid seeing the doctor.

children.name: at the slightest excuse
children.definition: for any reason, however unimportant
examples: She comes to our house at the slightest excuse.

children.name: excuse for (doing) sth
examples: What’s your excuse for being late this time?
I’m tired of listening to his excuses.

children.name: pretext
children.definition: especially writtena false reason given for an action, in order to hide the real reason : cớ, lí do
examples: His sore leg was a pretext. He just wanted a day off work.

children.name: pretext for
examples: Minor offences were sometimes used as a pretext for an arrest.
The incidentprovidedthepretextfor war.

children.name: pretext to do sth
examples: She couldn’t find a pretext to visit Derek at home.

children.name: on/under the pretext of doing sth
examples: He used to spend hours at her house on the pretext of giving her Japanese lessons.
Tom called at her apartment on the pretext of asking for a book.

children.name: on/under the pretext that
examples: He left immediately on the pretext that he had a train to catch.
He’ll phoneon some pretextor other.

children.name: explanation
children.definition: sth that you say which gives good reasons for sth wrong which you have done: lời giải thích
examples: This work should have been finished a week ago. What’s your explanation?

children.name: have an explanation
examples: Does the hospital have any explanation for why he died?

children.name: give an explanation
examples: The police gave no explanation for their actions.

children.name: ask for/demand an explanation
examples: When I asked for an explanation, the people at the office said they didn't know.|Furious parents are demanding an explanation from the school.

children.name: wait for an explanation
children.definition: expect an explanation
examples: She continued to stare at him in silence, waiting for an explanation.

children.name: owe
children.definition: sb
examples: an explanationI think you owe me some kind of explanation.

children.name: accept an explanation
children.definition: believe that it is true or correct
examples: The court accepted her explanation.

children.name: need/require an explanation
examples: We think the minister’s decision requires an explanation.

children.name: an obvious explanation
children.definition: one that is easy to see or notice
examples: There is no obvious explanation for his strange behaviour.

children.name: a satisfactory/adequate explanation
children.definition: one that explains something completely
examples: A bank must offer an adequate explanation of all its charges.

children.name: a convincing/credible explanation
children.definition: one that you can believe is true
examples: The author fails to provide a convincing explanation for the main character’s motives.

children.name: further explanation
children.definition: additional reasons
examples: He gave no further explanation for leaving, and she did not ask for any.

children.name: explanation for
examples: He offered no explanation for his absence at the previous day’s meeting.
What was their explanation for their decision?

children.name: without explanation
examples: The concert was cancelled without explanation.

children.name: when there is no reason for sb’s behaviour
be no reason
children.definition: /biː nəʊ ˈriːzən/  use this to say that there is no reason for someone to think or behave in a particular way:
examples: be no reason to do something:
▪ I know I’m late, but that’s no reason to lose your temper.
there is no reason for something:
▪ Please remain calm everyone. There is no reason for panic.

children.name: be no excuse
children.definition: /justification use this to say that there is no acceptable reason for someone to think or behave in a bad or unfair way.Be no justificationis more formal thanbe no excuse:
examples: ▪ ‘But she started it.’ ‘That’s no excuse.’
be no excuse/justification to do sth
▪ Ron may not be the most pleasant person to work with, but that’s no justification to fire him.
there’s no excuse/justification for sth
▪ There’s no excuse for such childish behaviour from a grown man.

children.name: groundless
children.definition: /ˈgraʊndləs/ groundlessfears, suspicions etc that are unnecessary because there are no facts to base them on: không căn cứ

children.name: ▪ Fleury dismissed our fears as groundless, though he was secretly alarmed
examples: .▪ A message from Interpol confirmed that our Inspector’s suspicions were far from groundless.

children.name: unfounded
children.definition: /ʌnˈfaʊndɪd, ʌnˈfaʊndəd/  worries, fears, hopes etc that are unfoundedare wrong because there are no reasons to have these feelings: không cơ sở
examples: ▪ I am going to prove to you that your suspicions are entirely unfounded.
▪ All the signs indicate that the general’s optimism is unfounded.

children.name: the words you write or say to explain sth
explanation
children.definition: a statement or piece of writing intended to describe how something works or make something easier to understand : lời giải thích, chú giải
examples: Each diagram is followed by a simple explanation.

children.name: explanation of
examples: I’ll try and give you a quick explanation of how the machine works.
Our guide gave us a detailed explanation of the system of government.

children.name: provide/give/ offer an explanation
examples: The ability to give clear explanations is the most important quality of the ideal teacher.
Can you give us a quick explanation of how it works?

children.name: account
children.definition: /əˈkaʊnt/  a detailed description of a process which also explains how it happens and what makes it possible:
examples: lời giải thích
account of
lời giải thích cho
▪ So far no linguist has given us a satisfactory account of how children learn language.
Đến nay không một nhà ngôn ngữ nào có thể đưa ra lời giải thích thỏa đáng về cách trẻ con học ngôn ngữ.
▪ Her account of the events of that day was wildly different from the first witness’s.
Lời giải thích của cô ta về sự việc ngày hôm đó khác hẳn so với nhân chứng đầu tiên.
accountnounREPORT
[ C ] a written or spoken description of an event
_Shegavea thrilling accountofher life in the jungle.
_Hekepta detailed accountofthe suspect's movements.
_Several eyewitnesses' accounts differed considerably from the official version of events.

children.name: clarification
children.definition: noun

children.name: an explanation or more details which makes something clear or easier to understand
examples: _Some further clarification of your position is needed.

children.name: well
children.definition: adverbbetter,bestREASONABLYvớilý do xác đáng

children.name: with good reason
examples: _She might well be the best person to ask.
_Ican't verywell (= It would not be acceptable to) refuse their kind offer.

children.name: case
children.definition: nounARGUMENTtrường hợp, cảnh ngộ, hoàn cảnh, tình thế

children.name: should
children.definition: modal verbREASON

children.name: used after 'why' when giving or asking the reason for something
examples: _Why should anyone want to eat something so horrible?
_Why shouldn't she buy it if she can afford it?

children.name: in the name of sth
children.definition: in the name ofsth(alsoinsth'sname)

children.name: (said or done) in order to help a particular thing succeed
examples: _Much blood has been spilled in the name of religion.

children.name: motivation
children.definition: eagerness and willingness to do something without needing to be told or forced to do it : động lực
examples: There seems to be a lack of motivation among the staff.
She enjoyed the excitement of her work. Money was not her only motivation.
sb’s motivation
efforts to improve employees’ motivation
Jack is an intelligent pupil, but he lacks motivation.
a high level of motivation
motivational[adj]
motivational speeches

children.name: excuse
children.definition: a reason that you invent to explain an action and to hide your real intentions : cái cớ (để làm gì)

children.name: excuse to do sth
examples: I need an excuse to call her.
She was just looking for an excuse to call him.

children.name: excuse for
examples: Any excuse for a holiday!
The conference is just an excuse for a holiday in New York.
